author: Laurence Russell
description:
England is an old place, and the raising of cities such as Bournemouth have been a blink of the eye to the great island.

The land now crawls with light and mortar, snaking, writhing over the ground and burying what lay beneath.

There are secrets in-between this new noise that has emerged in the recent centuries. Through the smog and behind the hum, is proof that the world was once free of human feet.

If a seeker were so compelled, they might learn of things in this world that once were, or things that have stepped aside for the procession of civilisation.

There was once a time when the world was not owned. To see it, you need only look for it.

Story © 2016 Laurence Russell, All Rights Reserved.

Editors Charlie Hargood and Verity Hunt
name: Seeker of Secrets

pages.content:
The land you stand upon is ancient ground. From the days this great island was carved out of the sea to today, much has changed. Creatures have thrived and been wiped out and cultures of mankind have spread and been swept away.

Like many places, this has been a changing land with a great many stories to tell, stories that await you even now. The meridians of nature swell inside you as they do in all things. Places of power are common in a land as old as this, you need only seek them out.
pages.name: Beginnings

pages.content:
The city of Bournemouth is arrayed around you, it’s urban influence reaches for many miles across the coast. Despite these distractions of metal and wire, history survives amongst the din of civilization.

The ancient villages turned suburban districts call for you from the east, whilst Westbourne beckons from the west. The great sea to the South has no use for history, and endeavours to sweep all days but today into the ocean and under the depths, but to the north lies Winton, with a past yet to tell. Choose your way at your leisure. The past will wait for you.t.
pages.name: Seeking

pages.content: During the construction of the pier, pieces of petrified wood were recovered from the sand, fossilised remains from trees that once grew on lands that have now been claimed by the sea. The sea claimed this victory around 7000 years ago, carving out the coast of Poole and Christchurch and flooding the woodlands south of them. Exposed to thousands of years of salt water saturation, these trees petrified as minerals of silica and calcite from the sea replaced organic matter, as if the boughs were turned to stone under the waves. The petrified remains are still kept at the Bournemouth Natural Science Society museum on Christchurch road.

hint.direction: Head to the end of the Bournemouth Pier

pages.name: The Sunken Forest

pages.content: The city is a young thing built on old ground. Founded in 1810, the city is a couple of centuries younger than even New York across the sea. In 1851 the population of Bournemouth was 695 people, 110 years on in 1961, it had grown to 154,286, and as of 2011 stands at 183,491. The city is a fast growing sprawl built over barrow graves and marshland that has consumed ancient villages in its wake. There was a time when this barren heathland was considered so desolate, it was a favourite haunt of smugglers avoiding attention from the authorities. Bournemouth claims much history, only a tiny fraction of which is its own.
pages.name: Bournemouth

pages.content:
The Bournemouth Natural Science Society museum stands ahead. Inside lies a collection of natural history specimens, fossils, rocks and minerals, photographic slides and two libraries.

The building itself is a sizable late Victorian home, listed as a grade II structure on The Heritage List, as a construction of special historic interest, of which there are 239 in Bournemouth.

Here, the Bournemouth public can learn about the natural sciences and ancient world. Bournemouth's school children are regular visitors.

The museum is open on Tuesdays, and many secrets of the natural world await you inside.

hint.direction: Go to 39 Christchurch Road to outside the Bournemouth Natural Science Society Building

pages.name: The Museum

pages.content:
The society, established in 1903, is a group of intellectual volunteers with an interest in the study and exhibition of science and natural history.

The disciplines of archaeology, history, astronomy, botany, entomology, geography, geology, ornithology and zoology make up the fields of expertise of its members, who also run the museum itself..

hint.direction: Go to 39 Christchurch Road to outside the Bournemouth Natural Science Society Building

pages.name: The Bournemouth Natural Science Society

pages.content:
Near to the society building you’ll find a large slab of limestone.

This is a Sarson stone, of the same ilk as the columns that comprise Stonehenge, as well as many other ancient British monuments

Stones like this are referred to as silcrete, formed from sand cementing together with naturally occurring silica cement which once covered a large portion of England formed during the Cenozoic period, beginning 66 million years ago and continuing today.

This particular stone travelled to Dorset along rivers which no longer exist during the last ice age.

The Celts saw something divine in these smooth, solid stones, which empowered their most sacred sites.

hint.direction: Go to 39 Christchurch Road to outside the Bournemouth Natural Science Society Building

pages.name: The Sarsen Stone

pages.content:
On this site once sat the second oldest building constructed as part of the Bournemouth territory, Symes Cottage, also known as Portman Lodge.

Tragically demolished in 1929 to make way for urban development, the cottage was constructed at the behest of Lewis Tregonwell for his personal butler, George Symes, whom Tregonwell wished to have living nearby his mansion at all times.

The construction of both the mansion and the cottage began at the same time, although the cottage was completed much sooner and the mansion took two years to build (despite this, the Mansion is thought to be the older structure).

hint.direction: Go to the corner of Exeter Road and Exeter Cresent

pages.name: Symes Cottage

pages.content:
This hotel was adapted and extended into its current form. Part of the hotel’s construction is made up of the Tregonwell mansion, the oldest building to be constructed as part of the Bournemouth area and an important piece of Bournemouth’s history. The rest of the building is competitively priced tourist accommodation.

Originally intended to be a holiday home for the Tregonwells, the mansion became a permanent residence for the couple. Their purchase of the plot of land upon which the mansion, and their butler’s cottage would be built upon in 1810 is commonly regarded as the moment that Bournemouth town was founded.

hint.direction: Go to the Royal Exeter Hotel on Exeter Road

pages.name: The Tregonwell Mansion

pages.content:
Cast in stone, you face a bust of the man Lewis Tregonwell (1758-1832)

Lewis Tregonwell, a captain of the Dorset Yeomanry, who organised militia patrols along the Dorset coastline east of Christchurch in search of smugglers and French invaders. By 1810, the threat had been dealt with and captain Tregonwell and his wife were free to retire. At the behest of Henrietta Tregonwell, who loved the heathland so dearly, the Tregonwells settled in the land they had once protected, constructing the first ever buildings in the original Bournemouth territory.

For this reason, Lewis Tregonwell is thought to be the founder of Bournemouth

hint.direction: Head to the layby outside the Bournemouth International Centre on Exeter Road

pages.name: Lewis and Henrietta Tregonwell

pages.content:
The terrain of the Bournemouth gardens was untouched by the hands of men until 1840, when development on the area began. It wasn’t until 1872 that the upper and lower gardens expanded to the point that they joined together into a single 3 kilometre span.

Before this, the area was made up of heathland, marsh and a large lake, making it unsuitable for farmland, pasture and building.

Now the land has been made decorative with specially selected flowers, trees and foliage, plant life imported from around the world and cultivated in British soil. The gardens are an example of the worldliness of Bournemouth in the modern age.

hint.direction: Go to the lower gardens

pages.name: The Bournemouth Gardens

pages.content:
The barren heathland upon which Bournemouth was built was not known for its abundance of trees. Where woodland did exist, it suffered from the erosion of the waves and the deforestation of nearby British communities. Meyrick park is an example of the deliberate cultivation of trees in the Bournemouth area.

When Bournemouth land was being auctioned off, the area of Meyrick Park was kept clear of significant development to retain an open, natural space in the heart of Bournemouth.

The park is devoted to leisure facilities including playing fields, tennis courts and an 18 hole golf course.

hint.direction: Head to Meyrick Park

pages.name: Meyrick Park

pages.content:
One of the three Grade I listed buildings in Bournemouth, The Parish Church of St. Peter is part of an exclusive group of historic structures of exceptional interest in Britain. Only 2.5% of listed buildings are given this grade.

Built between 1844 and 1879, the building is constructed from fine Purbeck limestone, quarried from the Isle of Purbeck to the south, these great stones are between 4 million and 145 million years old.

The church is described as one of the richest examples of Gothic Revival architecture in Britain.

The Church should be open for you to explore for yourself to see one of the most ancient and beautiful buildings in Bournemouth.

hint.direction: Walk to the Church of St. Peter near St Peter's Road

pages.name: The Parish Church of St. Peter

pages.content:
One of the three Grade I listed buildings in Bournemouth, The Church of St. Stephen is part of an exclusive group of historic structures of exceptional interest in Britain. Only 2.5% of listed buildings are given this grade.

Built in stages between 1881 and 1898, beginning with the foundation stone being laid in 1881, and continuing with the nave and aisles which were consecreated on June 10th in 1885. The Chancel and Lady Chapel began construction in 1896, again on June 10th and finally finished in 1898.

The flagstones of the Chancel, Sanctuary, and lady chapel are constructed from marble, imported from a startlingly diverse set of sources, from Ireland and France to Greece and even Africa.

hint.direction: Go to the Church of St. Stephen on St. Stephen's Road

pages.name: The Church of St. Stephen

pages.content:
One of the three Grade I listed buildings in Bournemouth, St. Clement’s Church is part of an exclusive group of historic structures of exceptional interest in Britain. Only 2.5% of listed buildings are given this grade.

Built between 1871 and 1873, St Clement’s Church was designed with an adjoining school to educate the children of Boscombe village, but was soon expanded into Boscombe British school in part by Sir Percy Florence Shelley, son of the seminal author Mary Shelley.

Built out of stone sourced from Bath, the church features elaborate encaustic tiling which sits in the nave, Chancel and Lady Chapel.

hint.direction: Head to the Church of St. Clement on St. Clement's Road

pages.name: St. Clement’s Church

pages.content:
Whilst the foundations for the Honeycombe Beach flats were being dug, a fossilised Nipa Palm Seed was discovered buried deep in the earth. The first of two such seeds to be discovered on the Bournemouth coastline.

The Nipa palm, also known as Nypa Fruticans is a palm commonly found along the coastlines of the Indian and Pacific Oceans, making it a strange plant to discover in Britain.

The plant may have made a home in British soil during the hotter climate of the Eocene period, 45 million years ago when the temperature was 7-10 degrees Celsius higher.

hint.direction: Go to Honeycomb Chine near Boscombe Pier and Sea Road

pages.name: The Nipa Palm seed

pages.content:
You stand at the edge of the land.

There was once a time when the land continued on to the south before it was claimed by the sea.

Under the waters, a chalk ridge runs from the Old Harry Rocks, at the tip of Swanage, all the way to The Needles, at the western tip of the Isle of Wight. 7000 years ago, this ridge stood as a section of the Southern coast of Great Britain, but was consumed by rising sea levels at the end of the last glacial stage.

Supposedly, there was once a time when the petrified tree trunks of the sunken forest could still be spotted, little more than graves, imprisoned under the tides.

hint.direction: Go to the beach near Undercliff Drive

pages.name: Bournemouth beach

pages.content:
You stand on Boscombe pier, opened in 1889.

The pier was one of many additions to the city in order to add to its tourist value and a resort town.

A far cry from the land’s origins as sparsely populated scrubland, characterised by tiny fishing and farming settlements.

In 1876 when Boscombe became a part of the city of Bournemouth, it’s resident citizens were appalled by the notion that their home would become a seaside attraction for the landed gentry. These families had survived in the desolate region for many generations against the odds, and were consumed with the urban flow of the rapidly expanding town.

Not much is known about these peoples and their villages, as their histories were swept aside in the current of urban development.

hint.direction: Go to Boscombe Pier

pages.name: Boscombe Pier

pages.content: You tread at the border of a humble suburb known as Pokesdown, once an old coastal village. However like many places in the city, Pokesdown's history is not apparent from walking its streets. Within its territory, two cremation cemeteries were uncovered on what is now Hillbrow Road in 1909 and yet more secrets were uncovered across Harewood Avenue and Kings Park in 1926 when 60 graves were uncovered. The urns reclaimed from these tombs now sit in the British Museum.

hint.direction: Go to Pokesdown, to the corner of Parkswood and Christchurch Road

pages.name: The village of Pokesdown

pages.content:
The name Pokesdown holds secrets of its own. Its two parts, poke and down can be broken and examined individually. Down simply refers to a hill or slope, poke is an alteration of the word “Puck” a mischievous fairy from the bard’s play A Midsummer Night’s Dream.

The name Puck originated from the myth of the old Irish Púca, elusive fairy meddlers and rogues, likely to help as often as they harm, which were popular enough to spread to ancient Wales, England and even Scandanavia and Germany.

Perhaps our countrymen believed this hill was haunted by púca interlopers, said to deceive travellers and mill flour for farmers at night disguised as mortal men.

hint.direction: Go to Pokesdown, to the corner of Parkswood and Christchurch Road

pages.name: The Pokesdown púcas

pages.content:
You now stand in the suburb of Boscombe. Boscombe was once an independent settlement, initially separated from Bournemouth itself by both thick hedgerows and barren heathland, but was consumed by the city’s expansion in 1876.

Boscombe is likely a reference to the old English word Boscumbe, meaning a valley populated by spikey plants.

Whilst this description is clearly no longer fitting, the name remains to this day, as a relic of the region’s past ecology.

hint.direction: Head to the center of Boscombe

pages.name: Boscombe

pages.content:
Integrated into the city in 1884, Westbourne was a more ancient settlement before being assimilated into Bournemouth.

Built over moorland, cut up by numerous chines, which made the land difficult to live on, traces of the ancient settlement are difficult to detect amongst the thriving urban district.

Now, the area has become a thriving commercial district, catering to shoppers and tourists, wishing to trade currency for baubles and finery.

hint.direction: Go to the center of Westbourne

pages.name: Westbourne

pages.content:
It was upon these cliffs along the beach and Alum chine that a series of excavations were organised beginning in 1878-1879 to unearth fossilised remains hidden in the rock, thought to be dated back to the Eocene period around 45 million years ago.

Over a lengthy excavation, some 10,000 fossils were recovered including a series of ancient seeds, fruits and fronds. The remarkable series of finds combined with the intrepid amateur experts who helped uncover, examine and exhibit the specimens resulted in the formation of a series of geological societies, only one of which has survived to this day, the Bournemouth Natural Science Society (BNSS), who can be found at 39 Christchurch road.

hint.direction: Head to the Durely Chine Cliffs near The Durley Inn

pages.name: Excavation of Durley Chine

pages.content:
As you walk the beach, watch the cliffs to your right for valleys in the land. Where the rock parts, roads have been built to connect the city to the beach, but these gaps in the land were not made by man, but by the waters that once ran through them.

You approach the mouths of Alum and Durley Chines, a chine is a steep sided river valley, many of which sat on Bournemouth’s coastline, branching off the great river stour, and cut through the cliffs to meet the sea.

Some of these rivers dried away naturally, leaving gaps in the cliffs, but many more were filled in to make way for the city.

hint.direction: Go west along to beach from the pier

pages.name: Bournemouth Chines

pages.content:
Unlike the surrounding districts, Winton was not an ancient settlement, and remained rough, untamed heathland as late as the 19th century, with the only sign of human habitation being a dirt track leading to Moordown village just to the north, another ancient landmark drowned in Bournemouth’s depths.

Moordown itself is thought to be the oldest settlement in the entire Bournemouth area, established in the mid bronze age at the latest, around 1650 BC around 3500 years ago.

hint.direction: Head to the center of Winton

pages.name: Winton

pages.content:
As you may have discovered at the water’s edge, the Dorset coastline once lay further to the South than it currently does.

This is the nature of the sea, writhing over the planet where it may. Faster and deadlier than the land it runs across; the sea is a frontier that none but fish may master.

The oncoming tides conquered the land and cut the bays of Bournemouth, Christchurch, and Poole along the Dorset coast. Who is to say when their thirst to drown the land will return?
pages.name: The construction of a land

pages.content:
In the age of Cæsar, a collection of Gallic peoples known as the Belgae escaped Roman rule in central Europe to settle themselves in Dorset around 50BC. Led by the chieftain Commius, the Belgae landed across the Dorset coast and the Isle of Wight, and spread a modest kingdom across Dorset, spreading into Wiltshire and Hampshire. Known Belgic settlements in and around Bournemouth include Hamworthy, Sterte, Corfe Mullen, Kinson, Stour Valley and Hengistbury.

Despite multiple negotiations with Rome, the Belgae would be forced to fight off a Roman invasion from the south, fighting many battles before being defeated by the second legion under emperor Vespasian to become slaves and labourers of a foreign empire.

The old families of Dorset are likely descended from these wise warriors of Belgae.
pages.name: The Belgae

pages.content:
a Gaulic king of the Belgae tribe, Commius cooperated with the Roman emperor in appealing for the British tribes to surrender to Roman occupation, and even fought with him against rival tribes. Despite Commius’ efforts, the Romans would ruthlessly betray him, attempting to execute him during a negotiation.

Commius vowed he would never trust the Romans again and took part in the Gallic wars to halt the campaigns of Cæsar across Europe.

After barely managing to escape the Romans and return to Britain after a devastating defeat at Alesia, Commius ruled the Belgae in Dorset as king until his death, leaving the Roman conquest of Britain in 43AD to his sons.
pages.name: Commius

pages.content:
By now you may have learned of the marshy, barren heathland that Bournemouth was built upon, and perhaps you have asked yourself why a city was built upon land that the British had largely avoided building on for millennia.

As a response to the large smuggling trade which relied upon the wilderness of the moors to hide their ill-gotten gains, as well as the Napoleonic threat from the South, development of the Bournemouth settlement was in the best interest of the Dorset gentry.

From 1810 onwards, construction of Bournemouth town began, taming the wild heathland of the Dorset coast.
pages.name: Bournemouth’s purpose

pages.content:
You have sought well. The past has been unravelled and the facets of knowledge have bent to your will. Be proud that you have walked such an elusive path in search of history. Whilst the sciences of the universe and the knowledge of people become wider and ever more necessary, the pursuit of history is something we move away from.

The future will always set us invariably further away from our past, and with this tragedy comes the erasure of our ancestors.

These lives stretching back into primordia that endeavoured to ensure the possibility of our future were those of heroines and heroes that have been too often forgotten. They are entities of knowledge and wisdom that have strayed into a darkness where the living cannot follow, and the secret seeker cannot look.

As we live in an ever expanding, ever forgetting world, let us endeavour to carry more of our past forward, so that we may not forget what we are.
pages.name: Journey’s End

pages.content:

We hope you enjoyed this StoryPlaces story. We would greatly appreciate your opinions on this new approach to story telling. if you have time, filling out the short survey linked below will help us to understand how to improve our application and design new location-aware story experiences. For more information on local natural science events and to visit the collection your self please go to

pages.name: Finish Story
